name: The Divine Hammer (Rogue 9 / Paladin 6 / Weapon Master 25)
author: Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
The Divine Hammer



Image source: https://i.pinimg.com/originals/c5/4b/f7 ... 036909.jpg


Greetings all!

This is my attempt at a charisma based paladin build draft with a decent AB (+6 AB from WM 25).

It features:
- Base AB 40, WF/EWF/EP, Blind Fight/Knockdown/Whirlwind Attack, Spring Attack for incredible battlefield mobility, Ki Damage / Ki Multipler / Ki Critical, 5d6 sneak attack, 4 attacks per round, Threat Range 18-20/x4 (17-20/x4 with a keen warhammer)
- 404 HP (644 HP capped), Fort 28 / Will 24 / Reflex 35, +4 to saves vs spells, +1 to saves vs traps fear and disease immunity, evasion, uncanny dodge

- +10 to AC from Tumble 40 and Armor Skin, add 5 to AC with Expertise active, +10-16 AC from Divine Shield (when you get it eventually), +1 AC with Dodge, +4 AC against attacks of opportunity
- Power Attack (+5) and Divine Might (+10 to 16) for +16 to 21 damage / hit - add that to your 18-20/x4 criticals - hooray!
- Taunt 42(52) for up to -6 AC to opponents (unlimited times / day)
- Very safe taunting of opponents with Maximillan Kane's Expertise/Taunt strategy and uncanny dodge I (to preserve Dex AC) and UMD (ie improved invisibility - 50% concealment, premonition +5/30 DR)
- Smite Evil for +10-16 AB once per day, Lay on Hands for 60 to 96 healing once per day

- 287 skill points, I chose Discipline, Taunt, Spot, Tumble 40, UMD 33 modified, Disable Trap (up to DC 45 traps), Open Lock (up to DC 45 locks with +10 picks), crossclass spellcraft 20, set trap 5(9), Search 13(15)

Overall it looked very nice with a lot of amazing synergies, great stats, something I would love to play, can do a lot of things pretty well (damage, tank, taunting, rogue skills, even healing!). 

CHA based paladins have a reputation for having terrible AB. However here with WM 25 and an effective Taunt ability the effective base AB is 40-46, depending on the concentration roll of your opponent, which matches any decent warrior build with 40-45 base AB.

A few extra feats like improved knockdown and extra smiting would have been nice but I thought overall this balance was best and the build is feat starved. The Rogue 10 bonus feat would have been nice too for crippling strike or epic skill focus taunt, but would have sacrificed some AB. I squeezed divine shield in late to accommodate late skill dumps and the ability to take divine might mid build.

I think any simple or martial one handed weapon can work well, I chose warhammer for the x3->x4 crit multiplier, bludgeoning damage and the +2 to threat range from Ki Critical, felt like the best choice. 

I think Human is ideal here to qualify for WM at level 12. Halfling would avoid exp penalties but you will lose the human bonus feat, 43 skill points and due to small stature will want to get improved knockdown, which means essentially losing two feats, and will qualify for WM at level 15 meaning AB is either dropped by 1-2 (-1 less AB from WM 22 possibly -1BAB if you add rogue levels) or you lose your late Taunt and Tumble/UMD/Rogue skill dumps, lots of suboptimal things for a build which is already feat starved evidenced by 3 pre-epic feats in epic levels (power attack, divine might, divine shield)

There's only one other Rogue / Paladin / WM build in the archives and EPA's ECB Filter Build search, Ithacan's A Holy Sword for Dark Days which is a strength based paladin Rogue 3 / Paladin 15 / WM 22, which is quite different.

I might redraft this one and post an update if it looks good!

Happy to hear your thoughts though. Can spend 8 more skill points to cross-class intimidate to put Rogue 1 at level 22 for +1 BAB

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I can see the mechanical side of the Pally/Rogue thing, no problem.

The RP side just doesn't work, however. IT DOES NOT WORK.  The mindsets are polar opposites.  It all revolves around Sneak Attack.  This thing is just not a Paladin thing.  Taking advantage of an opponent and striking them when they are not looking, helpless, and unable to defend themselves.  This is why Blackguards get SA and Paladins do not.

And it isn't "a few" as you put it - it's basically all RP type situations.  In action type environments, where only mechanical means are of interest, it doesn't really matter - there are no RP considerations. 

This is the heart of the matter right here (it's in the ruleset) :
The paladin is a holy knight, crusading in the name of good and order, and is a divine spellcaster. From 1st through 3rd edition, paladins were required to maintain the Lawful Good alignment. In addition, compared with other classes the paladin class has one of the most restrictive codes of conduct and paladin characters are expected to demonstrate and embody goodness. Failure to maintain a lawful good alignment or adhere to the code of conduct causes paladins to lose their paladin status and many of their special abilities until they are able to atone.
To that, this specifically :
[Typical tenets of the Paladin code are as follows (though many variants exist):
  • A Paladin must be of Lawful Good alignment.
  • A Paladin may never willfully commit an Evil act.
  • A Paladin cannot associate with any character who persistently commits acts which would cause the Paladin him/herself to Fall – notably Evil creatures.
  • A Paladin must remain truthful and forthright at all times.
  • A Paladin must give fair warning and due quarter to enemies.
  • A Paladin holds stealth, subterfuge, attack from the rear, missile weapons and especially poison as weapons of last resort.

The most important points being the last two here - and as SA cannot be "turned off (that would be cool)" and is always on, it is not something that a Paladin would do, unless there was no other option available.

A Rogue, on the other hand, always has SA "on" - meaning any situation that applies to allow SA, a Rogue automatically does.  This is in direct conflict with the Code of Conduct, and as such, would cause the fall of a Paladin immediately if used indiscriminately and without consideration, not to mention if used deliberately whenever possible.

If one wants to have a "divine rogue agent" - go Divine Champion/Rogue.  Or Blackguard/Rogue.  Or Cleric/Rogue.

It's like the "change alignment" builds (especially those that do multiple times).  Mechanically, it's there.  It's just for the most part, no DM is going to allow it - unless it is under special circumstances because of the conflicts of natures.  One that I would allow is the fallen Paladin/Blackguard "anti-paladin" schism.  It's a pretty famous trope imo, and one that should be the exception to the rule.

But a Barbarian that then changes alignment to Lawful to become a Monk, then changes back to Chaotic to advance as a Barbarian/Bard again, then back to Lawful to do a skill dump as a Mon, then back again to Barbarian/Bard, etc, that is just a mechanical technique that really isn't going to fly RPwise.  Especially when it has to happen at specific levels...like, planned out.  Ain't gonna happen.

And that is the gist of it.

If we were playing 4th or so, where the Lawful Good requirement and the Code of Conduct rules were changed, I would have no problem with Paladin/X.  But as NWN is 3.0, there it is.

Now, one can play with houserules.  Good ol' homebrew.  That's basically what PWs, Mods, etc are when they deviate from the ruleset.  And I have no problem with that.  None at all.  But when peeps pontificate that it should always be allowed, and that "only a few" (what a crock!) is the basis for their argument, then yeah, I have to speak up.

If you firmly are of the mindset that it should always be allowed, according to the rules, then show me where in the ruleset that we are using (what NWN is based on) that it states this.

I have.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I do respect your point of view here Web. And I have played enough paladins to understand what the rule book means with the class.

Another way of looking at it is to look at the rogue class and try to figure out what kind of characters that are rogues. Originally the class was the thief class and rogue has evolved directly from that. But somehow the class has changed in some important ways. It now is possible to have a lawful good rogue! You can also choose freely what skills you want to focus on. You may ask what kind of character a LG rogue is supposed to be. You don't have to make the character a pickpocket. You can just avoid taking the skill. And open lock doesn't necessarily have to involve stealing or burglary. You can use it to gain entrance when you are going to arrest some outlaw. You have SA, but it is not always on. It only comes into play with KD, flank or surprise attack. A typical LG rogue character from fiction could be Macgyver. Think resourceful, problem solver, skillful, smart and versatile.
I'm not saying that the core of a lawful good rogue is anything near the arch-typical paladin.

When I roleplay - I mean really roleplay - in a way where I try to make an interesting character with several different and sometimes conflicting traits, my paladins tend to have a broader personality than the arch type, simply by being human. Sometimes that is expressed with multiclassing.
Here somewhere is a small common ground or a niche where the two classes sometimes can overlap. But I clearly see the point  where the paladin strays too far from his path and becomes a fallen paladin.

As for game mechanics - I have no problem with the mix. It is not the best synergy, I would say cleric /rogue is far better. But sometimes it is fun to experiment with the classes just to see what build I can make.

Spoiler This is my personal point of view and does not represent the guild in any way
